Dear ___,

This letter serves as the discharge summary for your recent hospital stay, spanning from February 10, 2024, to February 14, 2024. You were admitted with notable symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever, which were indicative of a pulmonary infection. 

On February 10, 2024, upon admission, the diagnosis established was lobar pneumonia of unspecified organism, coded as J18.1. A chest X-ray conducted on the same day revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, corroborating the diagnosis of pneumonia. Empirical antibiotic therapy with intravenous Amoxicillin was promptly initiated.

During your stay, daily monitoring of vital signs, including temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation, was consistently conducted. Upon admission, your temperature registered at 38.5°C, with an oxygen saturation level of 92%. Over subsequent days, your vital signs showed significant improvement, with your temperature eventually normalizing to 36.5°C and oxygen saturation stabilizing at 98% by February 13, 2024.

Laboratory results demonstrated an initial elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 60 mg/L and white blood cell count (WBC) of 12 x10^9/L, both indicative of an active infection. These inflammatory markers trended downward over the course of your treatment, with the CRP reducing to 20 mg/L and WBC to 7 x10^9/L by February 13, 2024.

Your treatment regimen initiated with Amoxicillin IV at 500 mg every 8 hours, subsequently adjusted to 250 mg daily, and eventually transitioned to an oral administration of 250 mg as your condition improved. Additionally, Atorvastatin was administered nightly. Supportive care with Paracetamol was provided as needed for symptom control.

Ward rounds conducted daily indicated progressive improvement in your condition with steady declines in CRP and WBC, leading to the decision to plan for discharge. By February 13, 2024, you displayed notable recovery, no adverse reactions were reported, and you were deemed ready for discharge planning.
